conclusion: In the process of chip manufacturing, ion implantation is a crucial step. Ions are accelerated and enter a velocity selector horizontally, then pass through a magnetic analyzer, which selects ions with a specific charge-to-mass ratio. Subsequently, the ions are deflected by a deflection system and implanted into a wafer lying in the horizontal plane.

The uniform magnetic fields in the velocity selector, magnetic analyzer, and deflection system all have a magnetic induction magnitude of B, directed outward perpendicular to the plane of the paper. The uniform electric fields in the velocity selector and deflection system have an electric field magnitude of E, directed vertically upwards and outward perpendicular to the plane of the paper, respectively.

The cross-section of the magnetic analyzer is a quarter-circular ring with inner and outer radii of R1 and R2, respectively, with small apertures at the center positions M and N at its ends. In the deflection system, the electric and magnetic fields are distributed within the same cube with side length L. The bottom of the deflection system is parallel to the horizontal plane of the wafer, and the distance between them is L as well.

When no electric or magnetic field is applied to the deflection system, the ions are injected vertically onto point O on the wafer (which is the origin of coordinates in the figure, with the x-axis directed outward perpendicular to the paper). The entire system is in a vacuum, and the gravitational force on ions is negligible.
The deflection angles of ions caused by the electric and magnetic fields are both small. When α is small, we have sin(α) ≈ tan(α) ≈ α, and cos(α) ≈ 1 - (1/2)α².

The velocity selector consists of perpendicular electric and magnetic fields, with the electric field E directed vertically upwards and the magnetic field B directed outward perpendicular to the plane of the paper.

premise: In a velocity selector, ions with velocity v experience no net force when the electric force equals the magnetic force: qE = qvB.
conclusion: The velocity of the ions passing through the velocity selector is v = E/B.
The magnetic analyzer is a quarter-circular ring with inner radius R1 and outer radius R2, and it has small apertures at positions M and N.

premise: The radius of the circular motion of ions in the magnetic analyzer is determined by the average of the inner and outer radii: R = (R1 + R2)/2.
conclusion: The radius of the circular motion of the ions emitted from the center aperture N of the magnetic analyzer is R = (R1 + R2)/2.

premise: For circular motion in the magnetic analyzer, the centripetal force is provided by the magnetic force: mv²/R = qvB.
conclusion: The charge-to-mass ratio of the ions is q/m = v/(RB).
